metadata.title: Vanadium-embedded mesoporous carbon microspheres as effective catalysts for selective aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furfural into 2, 5-diformylfuran

Vanadium-embedded mesoporous carbon microspheres as effective catalysts for selective aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furfural into 2, 5-diformylfuran Jun Zhao a Xiaoping Chen a Yonghua Du b Yanhui Yang a ⁎ Jong-Min Lee a ⁎ a School of Chemical and Biomedical University, Nanyang Technological University, 62 Nanyang Drive, 637459, Singapore School of Chemical and Biomedical University Nanyang Technological University 62 Nanyang Drive 637459 Singapore b Institute of Chemical and Engineering Sciences, 1 Pesek Road, Jurong Island, 627833, Singapore Institute of Chemical and Engineering Sciences 1 Pesek Road, Jurong Island 627833 Singapore ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Vanadium-embedded mesoporous carbon microspheres have been successfully synthesized and applied in the aerobic oxidation of HMF to DFF. Vanadium dioxide (VO2) embedded mesoporous carbon spheres (V-CS) were synthesized by a facile hydrothermal method followed by post thermal treatments in air. The V-CS materials were used as catalysts in the aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) using atmospheric oxygen as the oxidant. The effect of reaction time, temperature, catalyst loading and solvents on the reaction were investigated. Under optimized reaction conditions, a DFF yield of 99% can be achieved. The physical and chemical properties of the catalysts were studied by FESEM, BET, XRD, FTIR, Raman, XANES and element analysis. The characterization results evidenced that the micro/mesoporous structure of the carbon spheres along with the highly dispersed vanadium dioxide species is responsible for the excellent catalytic performance. The post thermal treatment was the key step to afford the superior V-CS catalysts successfully. In addition, the catalyst did not have any significant loss in activity during the recycling test, showing good reusability. Keywords 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furfural 2, 5-Diformylfuran Oxidation Vanadium oxide Biomass 1 Introduction Biomass has recently attracted much attention as a promising renewable feedstock for the production of fuels and valuable chemicals because of the abundance, high energy content, sustainability, and biodegradability of biomass [1,2]. In particular, efforts have been devoted to the transformation of biomass into highly valuable monomers, pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals [3,4]. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), generated from the dehydration of hexose such as glucose or fructose, has been identified as a prominent biomass-derived platform molecule that can be readily oxidized to several important furan chemicals, such as 2, 5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylicacid (FFCA), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA) and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDA) [5–8]. Among these furan derives, DFF and FDA are the potential precursors for polymer production. For instance, FDA can serve as an alternative for isophthalic tand erephthalic acids in the synthesis of furan-based polymers [9–11]. As one of the most important HMF oxidation products, DFF is considered to be a potential chemical intermediate and can be employed successfully in producing pharmaceuticals, antifungal agents, furanic biopolymers and furan-urea resins [12–15]. However, the selective oxidation of HMF to DFF remains challenging due to the high reactivity of aldehyde functional groups. Various catalytic systems have been developed towards the selective oxidation of HMF to DFF. In early reports, classical oxidants, such as pyridinium chlorochromate, NaOCl [11], 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxide (TEMPO) [16], have been attempted for the synthesis of DFF from HMF. Nonetheless, these approaches showed some drawbacks, such as high cost and large amounts of toxic waste. Thus, using molecular oxygen as the oxidant for the oxidation of HMF to DFF over heterogeneous catalysts can make the reaction economical and environmentally friendly. Silver-containing manganese mesoporous molecular sieves, Mn(III)-salen complex [17], Pt-ZrO2/SiO2 [18] and Ruthenium catalysts [19] have been applied in the aerobic oxidation of HMF. However, these catalysts were found to be unsatisfactory because of the over oxidation of DFF and other side reactions. Recently, vanadium-based heterogeneous catalysts, such as V2O5/TiO2 [20], polyaniline-grafted VO(acac)2 [21], zeolite-support vanadia [22] and vanadium support in poly(4-vinylpyridine) crosslinked with divinylbenzene [23] were studied for the selective oxidation of HMF. VOPO4·2H2O was also attempted for one-pot oxidation of HMF to DFF [24]. Herein, vanadium-embedded mesoporous carbon microsphere catalysts (V-CS) were successfully synthesized by a one-step hydrothermal method using glucose and NH4VO3 solutions as the precursors for carbon and vanadium respectively, followed by calcination at different temperatures (600, 700, 800, 900 °C), the as-synthesized catalysts were applied in the aerobic oxidation of HMF to DFF. The catalytic activity of the catalysts prepared under different conditions was studied and the catalysts were characterized with various techniques, such as SEM, BET, elemental analysis, XRD, FTIR, Raman spectroscopy and XANES. The V-CS catalysts showed superior performance in the selective aerobic oxidation of HMF to DFF. HMF conversion of 100% and DFF yield of more than 99% were obtained in a dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) solvent bubbled with oxygen at 120 °C after 9 h under the optimized reaction conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials HMF and DFF were purchased from Alpha. Glucose, NH4VO3 (Ammonium metavanadate) and oxalic acid were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich including and all the solvents. All the chemicals were used directly without purification. 2.2 Catalysts preparation The V-CS catalysts were prepared by a one-step hydrothermal method using glucose and NH4VO3 solutions as the precursors for carbon and vanadium respectively. Typically, NH4VO3 and oxalic acid (molar ratio 1:2) were dissolved in deionized water and kept stirring until the color of the solution became dark green. Then, 4 g of glucose was added into the green solution and stirred for 3 h. After that, the mixed solution was filled into a Teflon-lined autoclave (40 mL in volume) and maintained at 180 °C for 4 h in an electric oven. The dark color precipitate was collected by filtration and washing thoroughly with ethanol and DI water, followed by drying at 60 °C overnight. The as-synthesized sample was denoted as V-CS and then transferred to a crucible with a lid and calcined in air at different temperatures (600, 700, 800, 900 °C) for 1 h in a muffle furnace connected to the outside atmosphere. Control experiment was also conducted to anneal the V-CS sample in a tube furnace under Ar at 900 °C. These obtained black powders were marked as V-CS-600, V-CS-700, V-CS-800, V-CS-900 and V-CS-900-Ar. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) analysis was performed by using a Digilab FTS 3100 FTIR instrument in range of 400–4000 cm−1 using a standard KBr disk technique. Raman analysis was performed on a Renishaw 1000 Raman spectrometer of which the detection depth is about 150 nm. The physical properties of the samples, such as surface area and pore size, were determined by an Autosorb-6B (Quantachrome instruments) through the liquid nitrogen adsorption method. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns between 10 and 90° (2θ) with a resolution of 0.02° were collected on a Bruker Advance 8 X-ray diffractometer using a Ni filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm), operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The vanadium K-edge x-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) measurement was performed at a XAFCA beamline of Singapore Synchrotron Light Source (SSLS). Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) was used to study the morphology and structure of the catalysts on a JOEL JSM 6701 F instrument. A Vario EL III CHNS Elemental Analyser was used to study the elemental composition of the catalysts. The vanadium metal loading (wt. %) was determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) using a SDT Q600 instrument and alundum pans under air atmosphere. 2.4 Catalytic oxidation of HMF and products analysis The reaction was conducted in a three-neck flask equipped with a condenser. 30 mg of the V-CS catalyst and 63 mg of HMF (0.5 mmol) were dispersed in 5 mL solvent to form the reaction solution. Oxygen was bubbled at a flow rate of 20 ml/min when the reaction systems reached the targeted temperatures (i.e., 100, 120, 140, 160 °C). After the reaction, the catalysts were separated from the reaction system by filtration and the filtrate was diluted and detected on Aglient 1260 HPLC (Bio-rad aminex 87H column). The mobile phase was a H2SO4 solution (5 mM) at 0.6 mL/min of flow rate. The column oven temperature was set at 60 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterizations Fig.1 shows the morphology of V-CS series catalysts. As observed, the carbon spheres are monodispersed and the particle size ranges from 3 to 10 um (Fig.1A). The spherical morphology remains intact after the calcination. The diameters of V-CS samples do not obviously decrease even calcinated at temperature up to 900 °C, indicating the high stability of the carbon frameworks. The physical properties of V-CS catalysts were investigated with the BET characterization. The BET surface area for V-CS is rather low as shown in Table 1 , and no substantial porosity has been detected. However, the post thermal treatment significantly increases the BET surface area of V-CS from 60 to 550 m2/g (V-CS-600) and even up to 936 m2/g (V-CS-900). Both the pore volume and pore size showed similar trends. The V-CS catalysts become porous when elevating the calcination temperature. The largest pore volume and pore size are 0.528 m3/g and 22.6 Å, respectively (V-CS-900). Interestingly, the BET surface area and the pore volume for V-CS-900-Ar are even smaller than those of V-CS-600, indicating the remarkable effect of calcination atmosphere. The X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) spectra of the as-prepared catalysts reveal more structural information. In Fig. 2 , every sample exhibits a broad peak in the range of 10–30° which is attributed to carbon (002) interlayer reflection among irregularly oriented polycyclic aromatic carbon sheets [25]. This peak shifts towards higher diffraction angle and becomes relatively sharper after calcination, indicating the decrease in the interlayer space [21]. The other broad diffraction peak in the range of 35–50° corresponding to the carbon (100) diffraction peak becomes more evident when increasing the calcination temperature, implying the increased degree of ordered structure of the catalysts [26]. These two characteristic diffraction peaks suggest that the carbon spheres are amorphous. No diffraction peak attributed to vanadium species can be observed for most of the catalysts except V-CS-900, indicating the high dispersion of vanadium in the carbon spheres. The diffraction peaks attributed to vanadium species for V-CS-900 can be indexed to VO2 (M) [27]. Table 2 lists the chemical composition of the V-CS catalysts. The carbon content of V-CS is 56%, and it increases significantly after calcination at 600 °C and 700 °C due to the decomposition of hydrogen- and oxygen- containing surface groups, hence the oxygen and hydrogen contents of V-CS-600 and V-CS-700 are apparently lower than V-CS. The hydrogen content continues to drop when increasing the calcination temperature, while for the oxygen content, there is a shock at V-CS-800 in the downtrend, suggesting that the interaction between oxygen and carbon may generate oxygen surface groups, such as anhydride and lactone groups [29]. The vanadium content, as determined by thermogravimetric analysis under air atmosphere, increases from 0.95 wt.% (V-CS) to 5.12 wt.% (V-CS-900) along with the calcination temperature, which is caused by the loss of carbon during the calcination by the reaction between the carbon atoms or fragments and oxygen in the air atmosphere. This speculation can be confirmed by comparing the vanadium content between V-CS-900 and V-CS-900-Ar. The vanadium content of V-CS-900-Ar is remarkably lower than that of V-CS-900 because there is no oxygen to react with carbon to reduce the carbon amount under argon atmosphere. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) study has been performed to identify the surface groups of V-CS catalysts. In Fig. 3 , the broad band at 3426 cm−1 is assigned to the OH stretching vibration. The peaks at 2922 and 1388 cm−1 attribute to the stretching and bending vibration of CH bond. The peaks at 1702 cm−1 and around 1569 cm−1 are attributed to the CO vibration of oxygen containing groups, such as aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids or esters and the CC bond of alkenes or aromatic rings respectively [27]. The broad band at 1250–1050 cm−1 can be ascribed to COC stretch. Compared with those of V-CS, the OH and CH peak intensity of the annealed samples decreases gradually as the calcination temperature increases. V-CS-900-Ar shows weak peaks of COC and CO compared with the other samples. These changes are consistent with the element changes in Table 2. The V-CS catalysts are further characterized by Raman as shown in Fig. 4 . Two peaks attributed to the D and G bands are observed for each sample. The peak at around 1340 cm−1 is assigned to the disordered structure of the carbon microspheres while the peak at around 1600 cm−1 corresponds to the presence of crystalline graphitic carbon. The ID/IG values of all the catalysts are larger than 0.5, indicating the high content of defects in the graphite sheets for the amorphous carbon structure [21]. The value of ID/IG for V-CS is 0.58, this value increases dramatically to 1.41 after calcining at 600 °C, and further increases to 1.86 when increasing the calcination temperature to 900 °C due to the carbon sheets’ microstructure changes in the carbon spheres at the high temperatures. Though calcined at the same temperature, V-CS-900-Ar affords a lower ID/IG value than V-CS-900 due to the different atmosphere during the calcination. Due to the highly dispersed nature of vanadium species, the techniques above are insufficient to provide characterization on the state of vanadium species. X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) measurements were carried out to explore the coordination and oxidation state of the vanadium species of these catalysts. A dramatic change in the XANES spectra for the catalysts before and after calcination is observed in Fig.5 . The spectra of V-CS calcined at 600, 700, 800 and 900 °C are comparable, indicating a similar local environment of vanadium. By comparing with the reference samples, it is concluded that the local coordination and oxidation state of VOx embedded in the carbon sphere after calcination are similar to those of VO2, suggesting that the calcination promotes the evolution of VOx species to form VO2 [30]. In addition, the oscillation magnitudes of the samples are weaker than that of VO2 because the samples are in an amorphous state. 3.2 Catalytic performance of catalysts 3.2.1 Catalytic oxidation of HMF over V-embedded carbon spheres The catalytic performance of these V-CS catalysts was evaluated in the aerobic oxidation of HMF with oxygen under atmospheric pressure. The dosage of each catalyst is different in order to ensure the amount of VO2 is equal in the reaction due to the variation of VO2 loadings. As shown in Fig.6 , a low HMF conversion of 0.77% is obtained when using V-CS as the catalyst prior to the post treatment. After calcining at high temperatures, the activities of the catalysts increase significantly. HMF conversion of 34.13% and DFF yield of 30.93% were obtained in the presence of V-CS-600. Moreover, the conversion of HMF and yield of DFF increase with the elevation of calcination temperature. These results demonstrate that the VO2 is encapsulated by the carbon sphere, leading to poor exposure of catalytic active site to the reactants when using V-CS as the catalyst. After calcining at high temperatures, the porous structure improved the contact between HMF and VO2, thus, the HMF conversion and DFF yield increase from 34.13% and 30.93% to 63.00% and 62.95%, respectively as the calcination temperature increase from 600 to 800 °C. Although the surface area and pore volume of V-CS-900 are larger than V-CS-800, the HMF conversion and DFF yield of V-CS-900 are poorer than those of V-CS-800 due to the aggregation of VO2 in V-CS-900, which is confirmed by the XRD. Due to the lack of oxygen in the calcination, the surface area and pore volume of V-CS-900-Ar are remarkably smaller than those of the catalysts calcined in air, the activity over this particular catalyst is lower than the other catalysts. Therefore, V-CS-800 is the most efficient catalyst for the catalytic oxidation of HMF to DFF. 3.2.2 Effect of solvents on the catalytic oxidation of HMF to DFF To optimize the product selectivity, the oxidation of HMF was conducted in various solvents. Table 3 shows that the conversion and DFF yield are greatly affected by the types of the solvents. As strong polar and high boiling point solvents, DMSO and DMF are found to be effective for the selective oxidation of HMF. DFF yield of 62.95% can be obtained from DMSO, which is higher than that of 30.34% in DMF under the same reaction conditions. High HMF conversions are also obtained in aromatic solvents, such as toluene and dimethylbenzene with a large variation of selectivity towards DFF. HMF conversions are poor in the other solvents, such as isoamyl alcohol and n-methyl-2-pyrrolidone, which might be the result of strong interaction between the solvent and the catalytic active sites since the heteroatoms N and O in the solvent molecules can work as the electron donor. Toluene (nonpolar solvent) affords HMF conversion of 99% which is higher than those in DMSO and DMF under the conditions. The possible speculation is that the active sites (VO2) are located in the organic carbon layer, which is easier for the aromatic solvents with lower polarity to bring the HMF to the activity sites, leading to high reaction efficiency. Therefore, according to the above results, it is difficult to make a simple and direct relevance between the solvent polarity and the catalytic activity, which is consistent with the conclusion reported by Riisager et al. [22] and Chen et al. [21]. In this study, DMSO is the optimal solvent for the conversion of HMF to DFF. Because DFF is a low polar compound, it can be separated from the reaction systems by liquid-liquid extraction [31]. 3.2.3 Effect of temperature and time on the catalytic oxidation of HMF to DFF The effects of reaction temperature and reaction time on the selective oxidation of HMF over V-CS-800 in DMSO are showed in Fig. 7 . The reactions are conducted at 100, 120, 140 and 160 °C spanning a 30 h time period. The HMF conversion and DFF yield are obtained as 12.85% and 11.39% respectively when the reaction is conducted at 100 °C after 2 h. HMF conversion increases to 42.78% at the same reaction time when the reaction temperature increases to 120 °C. The DFF yield sharply increases from 11.39% at 100 °C to 74.82% at 160 °C in 2 h. Fig. 7 also shows that the time-changing trend of HMF conversion and DFF yield is significantly influenced by reaction temperature. When conducting the reaction at 100 °C, the HMF conversion and DFF yield increase over time—specifically, HMF conversion and DFF yield are 12.5% and 11.39%, respectively after 2 h while these values increase to 81.74% and 79.85% after 30 h. Similar phenomenon occurs when the reaction temperature is increased to 120 °C. HMF conversion and DFF yield reach 86.34% and 85.79%, respectively in 8 h. When the reaction temperature is higher than 140 °C, there is a turning point for DFF yield versus time though the HMF conversion keeps growing. A DFF yield of 76.80% is achieved in 8 h at 140 °C, then the DFF yield starts decreasing. The inflection point for the growth of DFF yield appears earlier and subsequently declines by up to 17% after 30 h when the reaction temperature is further increased to 160 °C. The optimal reaction temperature for synthesis of DFF from HMF is 120 °C according to the above results, as higher reaction temperature causes the over oxidation of HMF to by-products, such as FFCA and FDA at a longer reaction time [32]. 3.2.4 Effect of catalyst to substrate ratio on the catalytic oxidation of HMF to DFF The dosage of catalyst is also a crucial factor for the reaction optimization. Fig. 8 shows the relations among HMF conversion, DFF yield and ratio of metal to substrate. HMF conversion and DFF yield increase significantly when increasing the catalyst amount. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the conversion of HMF and yield of HMF reach 100% and 99%, respectively with the increase of ratio of vanadium to HMF as nearly 2 wt.%. 3.3 Catalyst recycling experiments The reusability of the V-CS-800 catalyst was investigated by conducting five consecutive runs in DMSO. Prior to the recycle, the catalyst was washed thoroughly with the corresponding solvent and ethanol and dried overnight at 80 °C. The results in Fig. 9 show that the yield of DFF almost remains unchanged even after being used for five times. Recently, PVP-1/VO catalyst has been developed by Navarro et al. for HMF oxidation [21]. The performance of the catalyst decreased significantly due to the vanadium leaching. Vanadium phosphate oxide, synthesized by Dumeignil et al. also showed a decrease in the catalytic activity for the conversion of HMF to DFF during the recycling test owing to the change in the catalyst structure which reduced the number of accessible reactive vanadium centers [33]. Riisager et al. reported the loss of activity of the zeolite-supported vanadium catalyst in the stability test as a result of the vanadium leaching and site blocking [22]. In this study, TGA result shows that the vanadium content of V-CS-800 remains the same after the reusability test, suggesting the strong interaction between the vanadium species and the carbon support. 4 Conclusions In summary, vanadium-embedded mesoporous carbon microspheres have been successfully synthesized by a facile hydrothermal method. This vanadium catalyst was highly active and robust for selective oxidation of HMF to DFF after calcining in air at high temperature. The catalytic reaction was carried out under an atmospheric pressure in mild conditions with low catalyst loading. Under optimized reaction conditions, HMF conversion and DFF yield reached 100% and 99%, respectively over V-CS-800 catalyst that was calcined at 800 °C. The excellent activity was attributed to the mesoporous structure of the catalyst with large surface area, which allowed the free movements of reactants and products and enhanced the contact between reactants and active sites. Through the thermal treatment, the VO2 species as active catalytic centers were highly dispersed within the mesoporous carbon matrixes, showing improved catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: Vanadium dioxide (VO2) embedded mesoporous carbon spheres (V-CS) were synthesized by a facile hydrothermal method followed by post thermal treatments in air. The V-CS materials were used as catalysts in the aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) using atmospheric oxygen as the oxidant. The effect of reaction time, temperature, catalyst loading and solvents on the reaction were investigated. Under optimized reaction conditions, a DFF yield of 99% can be achieved. The physical and chemical properties of the catalysts were studied by FESEM, BET, XRD, FTIR, Raman, XANES and element analysis. The characterization results evidenced that the micro/mesoporous structure of the carbon spheres along with the highly dispersed vanadium dioxide species is responsible for the excellent catalytic performance. The post thermal treatment was the key step to afford the superior V-CS catalysts successfully. In addition, the catalyst did not have any significant loss in activity during the recycling test, showing good reusability.
coredata.dc:title: Vanadium-embedded mesoporous carbon microspheres as effective catalysts for selective aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furfural into 2, 5-diformylfuran
